body:
As mentioned in the Project Review, you shouldn't use `width` and `align` on the horizontal rule tag. If we check the code with the validator tool, it will point out this mistake.

![Screen Shot 2017-05-17 at 1.07.32 PM.png](https://udacity-reviews-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/_attachments/4203/1495040903/Screen_Shot_2017-05-17_at_1.07.32_PM.png)
.

Instead, you can simply just put `<hr>`.
Overall, good job with your page! :smile:
Alright, the spacing here looks good! :thumbsup:

It looks like this line is missing its `

`. It has the `

` at the end.

Great job opening and closing your tags in the proper order, so there is no overlap. This is known as properly nesting your tags. ```html Overlapping (not so good) Not overlapping (good!) ``` ---- ![Suggestion](https://udacity-github-sync-content.s3.amazonaws.com/_attachments/4203/1483476189/Screen_Shot_2016-12-23_at_9.50.19_PM.png) It looks like the `

` is missing. Whoops. Simple mistake.

There's a lot of spacing in this file. You shouldn't put a blank line between each and every single part. Instead, try to use blank lines to separate different parts. This helps to show what parts go together. ``` Example

Main Title

Some text here.

Some more text here.

Section Title

Even more text here.

Some other text here.

Section Title

Other text here.

``` A little tricky to see the blank lines between the last paragraph and the next heading, but I hope you get the idea. It doesn't have to be something exactly like that. Basically, just use your formatting to help explain what's going on. You may also find this read on formatting helpful: [Formatting & Indenting Your HTML](http://www.granneman.com/webdev/coding/formatting-and-indenting-your-html/)

Alrighty, the page looks good! :smile: I will be leaving some comments below.

If you'd like, you can check out the [Udacity style guide](https://udacity.github.io/frontend-nanodegree-styleguide/) that is used for FEND. Those guidelines are pretty good for helping you make your code nice. This will be something that comes up with future projects, and it'd be good to try to follow it if you can.
